Can't And Won't - Lydia Davis

Lydia Davis is known for writing some of the shortest stories you‚Äôll ever read ‚Äî and some of the most polarizing. A master of microfiction, she blends observation, dry humor, and everyday moments into strange little vignettes. Critics love her. She‚Äôs won a MacArthur ‚ÄúGenius‚Äù Grant. But her work often divides readers: you either sink into her fragmented world or bounce off it completely.

ANSWER: Can‚Äôt and Won‚Äôt

QUESTION: Will I read another book of ‚Äústories‚Äù by Lydia Davis?

You know when you‚Äôre scrolling Goodreads, and you see all these people raving about something ‚Äî 4 stars, 5 stars, calling it brilliant ‚Äî so you think, Okay, maybe I‚Äôll keep going? That was me. I kept reading, waiting for that switch to flip. Spoiler: it never did.

This book‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt even know where to start. Pages and pages about cows standing around. Obituaries turned into filler. That Letter to the Foundation piece? Never-ending. I forced myself through more than I wanted to, hoping for some kind of payoff or epiphany ‚Äî but honestly, I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs anything to get.

A friend warned me. Said Davis might not be for me. They were right. Maybe some of her other work hits differently, and I‚Äôd still give it a chance someday. But this book? Felt like a chore. I‚Äôve done more interesting things than read this, including staring at my ceiling.

The writing didn‚Äôt move me. The stories ‚Äî if you can even call them that ‚Äî felt flat, dull, and painfully unoriginal. The book was like a burnt biscuit. No jam, no butter, nothing could save it. And the fluffier it got, the more burned I felt.

I rarely say I hate a book. But here we are. It wasn‚Äôt just a bad read ‚Äî it was lifeless. Wordy in all the wrong ways. Some longer pieces dragged on, and I kept thinking they could‚Äôve been trimmed into a single sentence or scrapped altogether. I don‚Äôt even mind wordy or meandering prose when there‚Äôs something to hold onto. But this had nothing ‚Äî the imagery didn‚Äôt land, the diction was weak, and most of it felt like placeholders instead of finished thoughts.

Weirdly, the beginning wasn‚Äôt terrible. It gave me a sliver of hope. But I didn‚Äôt finish. I couldn‚Äôt. The disappointment was too real. I usually have a rule: if I buy a book, I finish it. But luckily, I didn‚Äôt pay for this one ‚Äî it was just sitting in my EPUB files. And I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt waste money on it.

I ain‚Äôt even leaving her Quotes.
